children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Future Generations would provide leadership and coordination across the United Nations System on the capacities, activities, and programmes required to support Member States in their efforts to implement the Declaration on Future Generations, approved by the General Assembly as an annex to the Pact for the Future on 22 September 2024 (resolution 79/1).

The Declaration on Future Generations reaffirms earlier commitments to the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations, to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, as well as to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, to the political declaration of the Sustainable Development Goals Summit of 2023 and to the Rio Declaration on Environment and Development.

The Declaration sets out the foundations to safeguard the needs and interests of future generations through concrete measures and follow-up mechanisms. In the Declaration, future generations are defined as all those generations that do not yet exist, and who will inherit this planet. It includes a commitment by Heads of State and Government to “equipping the multilateral system, including the United Nations, to support States, upon their request, in their efforts to implement this Declaration and embed the needs and interests of future generations and long-term thinking in policymaking processes by fostering cooperation and facilitating greater use of anticipatory planning and foresight, based on science, data and statistics, and raising awareness of and advising on the likely intergenerational or future impacts of policies and programmes” (para.30) and “fostering an organizational culture that is future-oriented and mainstreamed across the United Nations system in order to facilitate science- and evidence-based decision-making by developing diverse capabilities, including anticipatory planning, foresight and futures literacy, and systematically promoting long-term and intergenerational thinking at all levels.” (para. 31). It also comprises a decision to “convene an inclusive high-level plenary meeting of the General Assembly on future generations that will review the implementation of this Declaration during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly and provide updates on the actions taken to safeguard the needs and interests of future generations” and a request to the Secretary-General to “present a report on the implementation of this Declaration for consideration at the high-level plenary meeting to be held during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly” (para. 32).

The Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Future Generations will provide leadership and coordination across the United Nations System to meet the demands on the United Nations System deriving from this Declaration.

The Special Envoy will serve as a voice for long-term thinking and future generations at the global level, and would advocate, including in intergovernmental processes, high-level events and fora, for present generations to act responsibly to safeguard the needs and interests of future generations.

The Special Envoy will be responsible for developing a vision to fulfil the commitments of the Declaration on Future Generations and set strategic goals and objectives for its implementation. This will involve offering support and advice to Member States and providing leadership and policy guidance to the United Nations system on activities meant to accelerate the implementation of the Declaration, including through a better use of science, data, anticipatory planning, strategic foresight and futures literacy. The Special Envoy will also lead the preparations of the report of the Secretary-General on the implementation of the Declaration for consideration at the high-level plenary meeting to be held during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly in September 2028 and support Member States with the preparatory work, organization and execution of the high-level plenary meeting to be held during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly in September 2028.

Explanation of variances by factor – Overall resource changes
Other changes

1.432	As reflected in tables 1.210 and 1.211, resource changes reflect an increase of $1,062,800 owing to the proposed conversion of three posts (1 USG, 1 P-3 and General Service (Other level)) funded from extrabudgetary resources and the establishment of two posts (1 P-5 and 1 P-2/1) as part of the effort to meet the demands on the United Nations System deriving from the Declaration on Future Generations.
1.433	The functions of the Envoy would include the following:
(a)	Developing a shared vision to fulfil the commitments of the Declaration on Future Generations and set strategic goals and objectives for its implementation;
(b)	Offering support to Member States, upon their request, in their efforts to develop long-term thinking in their policymaking processes;
(c)	Advising Member States, as appropriate and with the support of other United Nations entities, on mainstreaming future‐oriented considerations in UN documents being deliberated;

(d)	Providing leadership and policy guidance to the United Nations system on activities meant to accelerate the implementation of the Declaration on Future Generations, including by undertaking a system-wide approach for the assessment, development, implementation and evaluation of policies and programmes that safeguard the needs and interests of future generations;
(e)	Promoting a future-oriented culture across the United Nations system, including by supporting better use of science, data, anticipatory planning, strategic foresight and futures literacy;

(g)	Leading the preparations of the report of the Secretary-General on the implementation of the Declaration for consideration at the high-level plenary meeting to be held during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly in September 2028;

(h)	Supporting Member States with the preparatory work, organization and execution of the high-level plenary meeting to be held during the eighty-third session of the General Assembly in September 2028;

1.434	The increase of $1,062,800 includes an increase of $901,300 under posts, for the proposed conversion of three posts, comprising 1 USG (Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Future Generations), 1 P-3 (Programme Management Officer) and 1 General Service (Other level) (Administrative Assistant), and the establishment of two posts, 1 P-5 (Senior Programme Management Officer) and 1 P-2/1 (Associate Programme Management Officer) (see annex II to the present report).

1.435	The increase of $161,500 under non-posts reflects provisions of $81,900 under travel of staff for the participation of the Special Envoy and his team in meetings of UN bodies and consultations with organizations, institutions, specialized agencies and other stakeholders to discuss assessment, development, implementation and evaluation of policies and programmes that safeguard the needs and interests of future generations; $59,100 under contractual services to cover the organisation of a workshop and the development of a website; and $20,500 for related non-post resources to support the proposed conversion and establishment of posts.
1.436	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 1.213.
